photo.description: Colosseum, Rome, Italy. Note that the area of rooms and passages in the middle was actually not visible in the ancient times as there was an arena on top of it. Currently there's just the small cover on the other side of the arena. The arena was also surrounded by benches in many floors so that people could watch the gladiators fight. Today you can only see those structures that supported the bench floors.

photo.description: The Colosseum or Flavian Amphitheater was begun by Vespasian, inaugurated by Titus in 80 A.D. and completed by Domitian. Located on marshy land between the Esquiline and Caelian Hills, it was the first permanent amphitheater to be built in Rome. Its monumental size and grandeur as well as its practical and efficient organization for producing spectacles and controlling the large crowds make it one of the great architectural monuments achieved by the ancient Romans [from the official website]
photo.title: Colosseum (Rome, Italy)

photo.description: The Colosseum or Flavian Amphitheater was begun by Vespasian, inaugurated by Titus in 80 A.D. and completed by Domitian. photo.title: Detail of the Arch of Constantine from The Colosseum in Rome, Italy

photo.description: Here is a view of the north side of the interior of the Colosseum. While no one knows for certain exactly where the emperor's box was located, it is generally believed to be on the North side, marked by the Christian cross. The cross was added by a Pope many decades ago as a memorial to the Christians who supposedly died within the Colosseum. Recent research, according to guidebooks, is that Christians were put to death at other sports arenas and that very few Christians actually died at the Colosseum, Part of a walking tour we did on our own, using guide books from home. November 27, 2011
photo.tags: rome italy colosseum collosseum ancient roman historic history ruin building construction gladiator sport arena november 2011 romeitaly
photo.title: The Emperor's Box at The Colosseum in Rome, Italy

photo.description: Here is a view of the north side of the interior of the Colosseum. While no one knows for certain exactly where the emperor's box was located, it is generally believed to be on the North side, marked by the Christian cross. The cross was added by a Pope many decades ago as a memorial to the Christians who supposedly died within the Colosseum. Recent research, according to guidebooks, is that Christians were put to death at other sports arenas and that very few Christians actually died at the Colosseum, Part of a walking tour we did on our own, using guide books from home. November 27, 2011

photo.description: Just after we entered into the Colosseum. We were using a Roma Pass, available for 25 euros, which gives free admission to two attractions, reduced admission to others, and free use of Rome's subways, buses, and light rail system. Best of all, the Roma Pass also has priority admission to all attractions. We were in the Colosseum in less than 2 minutes, as opposed to a hour and a half wait for those buying the tickets on the spot. The Roma Pass is a bargain. Part of a walking tour we did on our own using a couple of guide books from home. November 27, 2011
photo.tags: rome italy colosseum collosseum ancient historic ruin gladiator december 2011 arena sports roman construction romeitaly
photo.title: Entering the Colosseum in Rome, Italy

photo.description: On Sundays, the street along the northern wall of the Colosseum is closed to vehicular traffic. People take over the street and make a day of it hanging around the Colosseum area. Food and souvenir carts are also plentiful. Part of a walking tour we did on our own using a couple of guide books from home. November 27, 2011

photo.description: These guys dress as gladiators and will let you have a picture taken with them, for a fee of course. photo.description: On Sundays, the street along the northern wall of the Colosseum is closed to vehicular traffic. People take over the street and make a day of it hanging around the Colosseum area. Food and souvenir carts are also plentiful. Here we have just come out of the subway and are looking toward the Temple of Venus and Rome. Part of a walking tour we did on our own using a couple of guide books from home. November 27, 2011
